Time estimates are arbitrarily recalculated when altering time tracking settings

fields.description: when a sub task is set to resolved, the progress bar in the parent task indicates that the task has been completed. This should not happen until the sub task has been closed. Or, at the very least, the ability to configure this behaviour should exist. A "sub-task complete on closed"/"sub-task complete on resolved" workflow condition maybe.
fields.summary: Add ability to customize the criteria that indicates sub task completion

fields.description:
A parent task may have a number of sub tasks. If the parent task has a completion estimate on it and a sub task subsequently has some work logged against it, the time reported by the parent task is not affected.

The time estimate of a parent task should be the summation of the estimates of all sub tasks. The estimation of the parent task should be altered when work is logged against any sub tasks.
fields.summary: Time tracking of sub tasks

fields.description:
*Input*: (this used to work fine in previous versions)
{code:xml}
<JiraJelly xmlns:jira="jelly:com.atlassian.jira.jelly.JiraTagLib">
<jira:CreateIssue project-key="HSP" assignee="-1" summary="Issue summary"/>
</JiraJelly>
{code}

*Output*: (It knows the user that executed the script is admin - so username should be set in the context)
{code:xml}
<JiraJelly xmlns:jira='jelly:com.atlassian.jira.jelly.JiraTagLib'>
  <Error action='CreateIssueDetails'>
    <TagContents>((summary=Issue summary)(project-key=HSP)(assignee=-1))</TagContents>
    <ExecutedAs>user=admin</ExecutedAs>
    <ErrorMessage>Tag CreateIssue requires (jelly.username, jelly.project.id) variables to be set in the Context</ErrorMessage>
  </Error>
</JiraJelly>
{code}

*Workaround* Wrap the script within the Login tag.
{code:xml}
<jira:Login username="admin" password="admin">
...
</jira:Login>
{code}

The workaround fixes the error, however in this case, it doesnt seem to be needed...?

fields.description:
We need to update the docs so that we don't have an invalid search query., and also add a note on not having special characters at the start of a query.

------ Original Description ------
Hi,

As you say in your documentation (http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/v3.4.2/querysyntax.html) :

"JIRA supports using parentheses to group clauses to form sub queries. This can be very useful if you want to control the boolean logic for a query.

To search for either "atlassian" or "jira" and "bugs" use the query:

(atlassian OR jira) AND bugs"

So I tried this functionnality and I had an error.

See ScreenShot.

Thanks.

fields.description:
We would like to be able to restrict workflow transitions to a group based on the group the assignee is from, it doesn't seem like the assignee can effect the transition.
So what we need is this: user1 from groupA can create an Issue and assign it to user2 from groupB, but user3 from groupC needs to approve the Issue (workflow action) before user2 from groupB can start progress. 
So currently, you can restrict workflow actions to groups, we also want to restrict workflow actions based on a group's assignee.

fields.description:
Our product architecture (like many of you, I'm sure) is comprised of several "Layer Teams" - backend database processing, middleware web services, and front end Solutions. All of our Projects touch each of these layers in some fashion and force version updates to the packages. Right now we keep each of these Layers in separate projects so that we can Roadmap proposed and ongoing work. The problem with that is that for a given Solution the project is spread over several Layer "projects" and is difficult to actually get a complete status of the Solution project.

I may be missing something but is there a way to have a Master Project that pulls in or references issues from other projects so that status can be determined?  If not, what's everyone else doing?
fields.summary: Master Project support and rollup

fields.description: The problem might also be occuring on startup. However, this is difficult to reproduce.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-9728].
  {panel}

While writing tooling to integrate our development process with our Jira installation I found the javadoc to be non-existant for the exposed APIs.

Example:
http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/api/rpc-jira-plugin/latest/com/atlassian/jira/rpc/soap/JiraSoapService.html#addVersion(java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String,%20com.atlassian.jira.rpc.soap.beans.RemoteVersion)

Even if you don't document any of your other code I would expect to see documentation in any form of remoting service you offer on your product. It took quite some searching to find out that a sequence of -1 puts a version at the top of the roadmap.
fields.summary: Poor javadoc in the exposed API

fields.description:
When the dashboard has tabs configured and a session timeout occurs the user is dropped into a screen with an Add Portlet box, Home link, and a log-in link.  The Home and log-in links both are circular, in that they take the user back to that same screen appending the current destination to the url, thus building quite a large url with several clicks.  The user is dropped into the Add Portlet screen regardless of the link clicked and even happens on a page reload.

The only work-arounds are:
1. Click on Add Portlet which then redirects to the appropriate login page and then on successful login takes the user to the Add Portlet admin.  This of course is undesirable.
2. Have the user manually remove the extra url params and press enter.

Both of these fixes are not desirable for the business folks and are annoying to the IT folks.

Image 1. shows the url in the browser after a link click.
Image 2. shows the actual page content
Image 3. shows the url in the browser after clicking on the log-in link.
fields.summary: Session Timeout/Logout with tabbed dashboard broken

So we should either remove the link or created a mail server doco.

fields.description:
The workflow permissions work fine if the default JIRA work flow status are followed or mapped to. If say an extra couple of phases to cover testing are considered (independent of the assigned developer) then permissions  are less straight forward.

Create Issue -> Assign Issue -> Issue Progressing -> Issue Fixed -> Assign Test -> Under Test -> Test Complete -> Issue Complete

From the above it is possible to build such a workflow, but it is not possible to assign permissions to the non JIRA core phases. So we would like to be ablt to assign permissions to Assign Test, Under Test and Test Complete these don't match to existing JIRA phases so we are left with unrestricted access to these phases.

It would be great if more control of the assigning of the Issue could be undertaken after it has been initially assigned.
fields.summary: Permissions associated with user defined workflow statuses

fields.description:
Add "Closed Issues" to Created vs Resolved Issues Report, i.e. make "Created vs Resolved vs Closed Issue Report". The idea is this: in our team, it does not matter if developer says "issue is resolved", but tester must to confirm (i.e. "close" issue) that bug is really fixed and required functionality is OK. 

Created issues are about testers (and quality, of course): there are created issues, so testers work. 
Resolved issues are about programmers: there are resolved issues, so developers work. 
Closed issues are about testers again: there are closed issues, so we have some functionality done, because this functionality was tested at least twice. 

Graph can be nice (see also JRA-9696), because Closed issues is subset of Resolved ones and Resolved issues are subset of Created ones (if workflow is used correctly).
fields.summary: Add "Closed Issues" to Created vs Resolved Issues Report.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-9674].
  {panel}

I think the support request feature is great, but it shifts the conversation to email and away from where it belongs:  In an issue tracker like JIRA!

Here's how I think it should (ideally) work:

1) It should create an issue within the local JIRA
  - this implies you'd have to be able to set all of the things you would set for a regular issue, such as issue type, summary, security level, priority, etc...
  - it could also optionally imply that JIRA should ship by default with a project for tracking issues related to JIRA itself (I can't imagine anyone not doing this, but I suppose it's no big deal for folks to create their own)
2) The issue should be assigned to the user with the email address the support request is being sent to.  If one does not exist yet, it should be created (perhaps the system should get a username and description  -- aka full name in that case)
3) The issue would have the backup and log attached just as the email does.  The local environment might be good as an attachment as well -- it takes up a lot of room on the screen
4) On the atlassian end, the email should be imported into an issue at support.atlassian.com

Why keep it in both places, you ask?  Because until there's a portlet for watching issues on someone else's JIRA, most of us will only pay attention to what's in our own JIRA and it doesn't make sense for Atlassian to deal with support requests on everyone else's JIRAs.


Note that I've already implemented a workaround that works pretty well for me (see JRA-9547) and you'd have to deal with potential notification loops between the two JIRAs (see JRA-9617).
fields.summary: Support  Request feature should be more tightly integrated

Anyone, who has insight to this, please post guide/advice.

fields.description:
JIRA creates cookies with wrong domains which causes in certain circumstances strange behaviors.

When JIRA is accessable from "www.work.test.de" the cookies just contain as domain "work.test.de" (just domain with 2 dots).

When the firefox browser is configured (for security reasons) that only original cookies are allowed (see screenshot) then the work with JIRA with multiple open browser windows is very strange.

With best regards,
Alexander
fields.summary: JIRA cookies contains wrong domain

fields.description:
The open source website (http://opensource.atlassian.com) link to the atlassian-idea plugin download needs to be updated to point to the SVN repository.

Instead of pointing to the cvs repository download (on the xdocs/index.xml) page:

http://repository.atlassian.com/atlassian-idea-plugin/distributions/

it should point to the SVN dist repository:

http://svn.atlassian.com/svn/public/contrib/maven-plugins/atlassian-idea-plugin/dist/

The opensource website has been moved to a new server - so the orginal deploy goal does not work now.
fields.summary: Update opensource.com link to atlassian-idea plugin download.

fields.description:
Scarab can generate tab-separated exports of values. JIRA's CSV importer *should* be able to import these, because the CSV importer lets one specify a delimiter character. However it looks like JIRA may be trimming the entered character for whitespace (killing my entered tab), since the generated properties file has no mention of a separator char:

# written by PropertiesConfiguration
# Tue Mar 14 10:53:57 EST 2006
existingprojectkey = TP
importsingleproject = false
importexistingproject = true
mapfromcsv = false
field.Issue type Issue ID Assigned to Priority Resolution Status Summary = summary

Attached is the sample file I'm trying to feed to the wizard.
fields.summary: CSV importer can't import tab separated values file

  {panel}

jira does not appear to have an ability to control the types of object a specifi relationship type can attach to.

If this could be done then the UI would be improved 
   less choices to get wrong in the dropdown
   better filetring of the choices to relate to in the helper screens

Also the relationship data is likely to be more accurate, as the user is guided thorugh selection of the relationships thatthe designer thinks are appropriate

fields.description:
JIRA provides an excellent view of a roadmap, but in my view little or no support to aid the planning and maintenance of a roadmap.

To support some simple mechanism to enable the initial plans to be drawn up would significant aid my job, and also I believe be beneficial for many other users

I can describe the scheme that we use, and I hope the reviewer of this could determine if this is a suitably generic implementation to be used by other users, and therefore should be a feature of JIRA itself

The drivers that we have is that specific releases must support specific features that have been requested by customers, to support the specific features that they require in a build. Other thngs to consider are are build themes, and techinical or architectural issues that we have.


We have created some new bug types (Driver) and relationships (Requires, SupportedBy)

A Driver is some external pressure such as a agreed customer expectation, a internal business driver (e.g. development cost reduction, some theme) etc. A driver may have subtasks which are also drivers. Drivers are typically either some absolute binary measure, or a quantitive expectation. Drivers may have a required by date (typically if they represent or co-ordinate some external dependency)

A Requires relationship is used to map the features that contribute to a driver, but are not required by the driver.

A SupportedBy relationship is used map the driver to the are required by a driver

Requires and SupportedBy relationships are from a driver to a [driver, feature or enhancement]

When scoping a build we determine the features that we internally want to have in a build and also look at the drivers for that build. This is done by listing the drivers for a specific build target, and navigating all of the Requires relationships (for things that are not already in a previous build). If there is addition capacity in the build then the SupportedBy relationships are examined, and then other non associated work

This also gives us a crude way of managing impact.
 If one of our drivers has a date changes (forwards or backwards) then the analysis can be revalidated, and the changes made on-mass if this is considered appropriate.

If a specific feature is delayed in the implementation we can view the impact of slipping the feature to a subsequent release
fields.summary: provide features to suport planning and replanning of a roadmap

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-9631].
  {panel}

It would be nice to enable the following options in the Find Issues critera:

[x]  Changed or commented by (user picker with default: the Current User)

(and if the current user was the only option, it'd be less flexible but OK in most cases for me) 

That way I could have a pre-fab filter for "find all modified by or /commented on by me in the last 30 days" or do a custom search for something like: title contains "weblogic" and was commented on by me (with no date range).

fields.summary: Errors in JIRA Logs

fields.description:
It would be handy to have a way to union multiple filter's worth of results into one result set.  It should then be possible to feed said union into one of the portlets such as "Show Saved Filter" or "Two Dimensional Filter Statistics".  

An example user of this would be one of our development managers who wants to track results for users assigned to two seperate development groups (e.g. "Dev-UI" and "Dev-Communication" or something along those lines).  

Criticality on this is pretty low but the convenience factor would be extremely high :)
fields.summary: It would be handy to have the capability to "union" multiple sets of filter results

fields.description: I would like to suggest to provide the capability to filter our by component.  We have many components to our system and need to do reports of bugs against certain components.
fields.summary: Provide search capability by Component
